good afternoon I'm Kevin Barry from the University of Notre Dame and uh you'll
hear a similar story I think we I also can thank the same people an and John Paul whose last name I don't remember
who came I believe John Paul was a noted amum which may have been why we were on the list of potential collaborators uh
the hulet foundation was important for us our Focus for the years when the
hulet foundation was important was to to focus on courses involving The Human
Condition so we were looking at uh providing courses that focus on those
areas that were important to Notre Dame and that fit with our mission and and I'll just let you read those things for
a little bit um a little bit of the history of the University so 1842
founded uh our our next big anniversary is actually next year we'll celebrate 40
Years of women attending the University of Notre Dame um so so that's a a big
thing and I surprisingly as I've been looking at that history it's more common than I had expected that I I thought of
Notre Dame being somewhat unique and uh allowing the entry of women in that time frame but many universities shifted from
being male only to uh also admitting women in the 60s and 70s um the mission is is a key piece to
why we wanted to be involved in this so this idea of creating a sense of human solid ity concern for the common good we
feel like that by putting this information in an open environment we are contributing in that way and helping
to advance knowledge and at Notre Dame also with that knowledge put in the Catholic context especially for those uh
courses that deal with The Human Condition so some of the things that have happened over those times uh
Everyone likes to talk about father nuland at Notre Dame who was at least is one of the people who gets credit for
for uh the invention of synthetic rubber um so so there are some interesting historical things that have happened
till then uh we were completely governed by priests until the late 60s and so it
was only in the 60s that uh they added lay members to the board of the university and an R ocw site launched in
September of 2006 so as I mentioned we're contributing to the common good with
this by making these materials available to the world and I wanted to just mention a few specific courses uh one of
the things that we found that's been very rewarding is that in the context of
events that are happening in the world we've seen great variations in the traffic associated with the courses that
we offer in our site so these three that I list here in particular the cre language and culture course was one that
after the earthquake in Haiti began to get thousands and thousands of hits a month and in fact the the instructor who
contributed that course decided to make herself available to people that were trying to work with Haitians to help
them to learn some basic Creole and be able to work more effectively with the people in Haiti uh the Islamic Societies
in Middle East uh with the events that have recently been happening in Egypt and Syria has been a course that has
seen a huge spike in interest because it talks about uh cultures in the Middle East and and people are very interested
in understanding those types of things better and and then the last one on nuclear warfare when the uh tragic
earthquake and tsunami happened in Japan and there began to be news of potential
issues with the uh radiation from the nuclear reactors and how would that spread around the world the course on
nuclear warfare has a a significant segment on how radiation can be spread
through water and airborne and different things like that and so that section in particular it's interesting in that
course it wasn't just the course in general but that one specific section of the course began to get a very high
amount of traffic so that's been rewarding because our Hope was that we would put things out that people would
find useful and and this sort of I think connects to the ideas that uh Tim
O'Reilly spoke about this morning of the a finding knowledge that answers certain
questions and I think I agree with him that focusing things down is important or or having things with the right kind
of metat tagging and being searchable so that if people have a specific question they can find the answers and the
information they're looking for that's related to that uh one thing that they want to have answer um the other thing that I think is a
side benefit uh or well the the one that's a true benefit is helping Notre
Dame students since the hulet foundation funding uh We've broadened our offering
of courses and one of the things we tried to do is offer courses as open courses that are also courses that meet
the core requirements for Notre Dame students this allows them to use that material while they're in classes to use
that material to investigate classes that they might want to take and so it has a real local benefit that that's been important for us to try to have
some way to sell a local benefit because to be honest we haven't had the quite
the same strength of support at least financially uh it's been a challenge to
keep uh funding in place so that we can continue to add courses and so by adding some courses that have a local benefit
is an important way to make that something that the university sees as valuable and another thing that's
valuable to the university as many universities we are now moving in the direction of trying to be have a much
more significant Global president presence we've recently hired a provos
uh for internationalism which position did not exist before um and one of the things that the open course where
participation does is allows Notre Dame to be known as a place other than where
American football is played in places around the country so if people know about University of Notre Dame when I
travel around around the world it's frequently for the athletic programs or
if I say I I mentioned something about Notre Dame they think I'm talking about a cathedral in France and so um this is
something that we want to change and as the world gets smaller and smaller it's important for us that Notre Dame is
known as uh the high level academic institution that it is the history of us for the ocw
participation as I mentioned already the the launch in 2006 uh We've participated in many of
the global meetings um significantly this year was possible partly because of being in the US so one of the challenges
with funding As you move forward is uh sometimes traveling to the more distant locations can can be a challenge we now
have 48 courses published so our staff is one person Kathy Schultz and she does a tremendous job and recruiting faculty
and she does everything we use the edge of Commons framework that was developed at the University of Utah
as our framework and Kathy uh with an occasional student worker hired on when things get real busy uh handles all the
work of everything from copyright clearance to getting material out in the courses and conversion and all those
sorts of things uh one of the things we're proud of we made a decision early on that we wanted our courses to be very
complete so that we didn't end up having some courses that had a scarcity of material and others that had a lot of
material and um when Einstein uh open this is a Social
Learning Network site that they have phds in the discipline evaluate open cours where offerings and then after
their screen they decide to allow some of them to be listed on their site and others not when they last evaluated our
courses we had 42 possible courses that could be on their site 39 of them were
added to their site one was a course on the Notre Dame uh Honor Code which they
felt wasn't appropriate for a worldwide site and two others were in Spanish and they had no one to to rate courses that
were in Spanish so we were really happy that we were able to uh get all those courses included in their listings um
we've also been one thing that Cathy asked me to mention is we've been happy that we've tried to use other Creative
Commons licensed materials and building our courses and a significant example of that is our calculus for business
courses that we've added where uh the graduate student who built those was able to find applets that interactive
Java applets for a large number of the concept in this two semester calculus
sequence that were Creative Commons licens that are now completely integrated and and and embedded in a
course as opposed to just being Standalone in applet so it was a nice combination of the open courseware
movement combining with uh other Creative Commons licens material to create complete
courses and that is the end of my part of the introduction and I'll turn it over to Mary Lee
